node.title: FSP output
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
Why do I use different FSP preprocessing options (additive, multiplicative, schur), but using -ksp_view_pmat are jacobian matrix output?

Hello
Field splits are not just a different preconditioning matrix, they are also a sequence of steps to solve the linear systems.
This isnt shown by view_pmat
Guillaume

node.title: Trying to install an older app from 3 years ago
node.bodyText:
Bug Description

I am trying to install an app that was developed 3-4 years ago.
I already installed the latest version of MOOSE, and all tests ran just fine.
I have a copy of the app, when I put it in next MOOSE and make it, i  get the following errors:
CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:23:17: error: 'exII' is not a namespace-name
   23 | using namespace exII;
      |                 ^~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C: In function 'int createMesh()':
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:562:11: error: 'EX_VERBOSE' was not declared in this scope
  562 |   ex_opts(EX_VERBOSE | EX_ABORT);
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:562:24: error: 'EX_ABORT' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'PETSCABORT'?
  562 |   ex_opts(EX_VERBOSE | EX_ABORT);
      |                        ^~~~~~~~
      |                        PETSCABORT
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:562:3: error: 'ex_opts' was not declared in this scope
  562 |   ex_opts(EX_VERBOSE | EX_ABORT);
      |   ^~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:571:7: error: 'EX_CLOBBER' was not declared in this scope
  571 |       EX_CLOBBER,     /* create mode */
      |       ^~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:570:11: error: 'ex_create' was not declared in this scope
  570 |   exoid = ex_create("test.exo",     /* filename path */
      |           ^~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:583:11: error: 'ex_put_init' was not declared in this scope
  583 |   error = ex_put_init(exoid, "This is a test", num_dim, num_nodes, num_elem, num_elem_blk,
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:588:11: error: 'ex_put_coord' was not declared in this scope
  588 |   error = ex_put_coord(exoid, &coords_x[0], &coords_y[0], &coords_z[0]);
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:594:11: error: 'ex_put_coord_names' was not declared in this scope
  594 |   error = ex_put_coord_names(exoid, coord_names);
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:604:11: error: 'ex_put_map' was not declared in this scope
  604 |   error = ex_put_map(exoid, elem_map);
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:619:31: error: 'EX_ELEM_BLOCK' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'XTERM_BL                                                                      ACK'?
  619 |   error = ex_put_block(exoid, EX_ELEM_BLOCK, ebids[0], "PYRAMID5", num_elem_in_block[0],
      |                               ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
      |                               XTERM_BLACK
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:619:11: error: 'ex_put_block' was not declared in this scope
  619 |   error = ex_put_block(exoid, EX_ELEM_BLOCK, ebids[0], "PYRAMID5", num_elem_in_block[0],
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:622:7: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  622 |       ex_close(exoid);
      |       ^~~~~~~~
      |       pclose
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:628:7: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  628 |       ex_close(exoid);
      |       ^~~~~~~~
      |       pclose
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:631:11: error: 'ex_put_name' was not declared in this scope
  631 |   error = ex_put_name(exoid, EX_ELEM_BLOCK, ebids[0], "PYRAMID5 BLOCK");
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:633:7: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  633 |       ex_close(exoid);
      |       ^~~~~~~~
      |       pclose
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:638:7: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  638 |       ex_close(exoid);
      |       ^~~~~~~~
      |       pclose
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:642:11: error: 'ex_put_conn' was not declared in this scope
  642 |   error = ex_put_conn(exoid, EX_ELEM_BLOCK, ebids[0], &elements_pyr[0], NULL, NULL);
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~~
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:644:7: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  644 |       ex_close(exoid);
      |       ^~~~~~~~
      |       pclose
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:649:7: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  649 |       ex_close(exoid);
      |       ^~~~~~~~
      |       pclose
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/main.C:680:11: error: 'ex_close' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'pclose'?
  680 |   error = ex_close(exoid);
      |           ^~~~~~~~
      |           pclose


Interestingly, when I make it again, I get new errors somehow like the following:
CDD-MOOSE/src/materials/ComputeMultDecompStress.C:139:18: error: 'RankTwoTensor' {aka 'class RankTwoTensorTempl<double>'} has no member named 'mixedProductIkJl'; did you mean 'mixedProductJkI'?
  139 |   _tan_mod = _fe.mixedProductIkJl(_fe) * _dpk2_dfe;
      |                  ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      |                  mixedProductJkI
make: *** [/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.x86_64-pc-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1


Steps to Reproduce

I am just making the CDD-MOOSE app
Impact

I need to have the CDD_MOOSE, it used to work for me 2 years ago just fine.

Hello
There has been a lot of changes in 3 years.
I suspect exII is now exodusII_helper.
You should have a look at the current exodus output code to update this.
Then you should make sure you're up to date on this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/newsletter/2020/2020_04.html#c1ba1ef6-13a6-4210-bedb-0b691fec2ce7
Guillaume

Thanks for the reply Guillaume,
Actually, there is a lot of problem I am facing now, haha. so it seems like I would have to update the old app we built, which is actually a lot of work unfortunately. Take a look at some of the errors I am getting when I try to make
In file included from /home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/build/unity_src/constraint_Unity.C:2:
/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/constraint/KinematicLinearNodalConstraint.C:17:51: error: expected constructor, destructor, or type conversion before ';' token
   17 | defineLegacyParams(KinematicLinearNodalConstraint);

/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/materials/ComputeMultDecompStress.C:139:18: error: 'RankTwoTensor' {aka 'class RankTwoTensorTempl<double>'} has no member named 'mixedProductIkJl'; did you mean 'mixedProductJkI'?
  139 |   _tan_mod = _fe.mixedProductIkJl(_fe) * _dpk2_dfe;

/home/ahmad68/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/PostprocessorInterface.h:41:26: note: candidates are: 'static InputParameters PostprocessorInterface::validParams()'
   41 |   static InputParameters validParams();

/home/ahmad68/projects/CDD-MOOSE/src/auxkernels/DivergenceAux.C:31:1: error: specializing member 'DivergenceAuxTempl<false>::computeValue' requires 'template<>' syntax
   31 | DivergenceAux::computeValue()


/home/ahmad68/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/InputParameters.h:1820:24: error: reference to 'TransientTransport::validParams' is ambiguous
 1820 |   return T::validParams();

So I have a question, it seems like the link you've attached above would fix my problems after I update, i just wanted to make sure.
mixedProductIkJl'; did you mean 'mixedProductJkI'?, so the product ijkl was updated , correct?
lastly, I am not sure what it means by this error reference to 'TransientTransport::validParams' is ambiguous
1820 |   return T::validParams();
Thanks a lot for the help. Ahmad

The validParams stuff, eg most of the errors you are getting here, is a hard deprecation of an old way to define parameters for an object.
You will need to follow everything mentioned here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/newsletter/2020/2020_04.html#c1ba1ef6-13a6-4210-bedb-0b691fec2ce7
there is no other way about this.

mixedProductIkJl'; did you mean 'mixedProductJkI'?, so the product ijkl was updated , correct?

I think so yes. You can double check the rankTwoTensor documentation to make sure:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classRankTwoTensorTempl.html

Awesome, will work on that. Many thanks.
sorry, one Last question I forgot to ask in the last thread. I could not find the description for the function defineLegacyParams(), other than you just pass a constant function as variable, I couldn't find the documentation for this function.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/releases/moose/v1.0.0/doxygen/moose/ConstantFunction_8C.html

please remove this legacyParam function entirely, this is not how we do parameters anymore.
The newsletter post has the information you need
awesome thanks, I will work ont it.

I have an updated code, and it compiles, you can mark this as done. thanks for the help.
Running into issues with the input file, about to open up a new discussion

node.title: Laplacian of a scalar field
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
Is there anyway in MOOSE to get the Laplacian of a scalar field?
I need to compute d2c/dx2 but do know how to do it.
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
By scalar field you mean a regular variable?
Do you mean to use this in a residual or just for postprocessing?
Guillaume
Yes, I meant a regular variable. I need it for post processing.

You can look at second derivatives on variables (retrieve using getVar())
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classMooseVariableFE.html#a6084c139e379961bfcc3f5ed97d181f4
or use the Coupleable interface, same as for values, first derivatives etc
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classCoupleable.html#a905ce7bd997b1374a18b0c7a3d3389a5

Thank you so much. In one part of my code, I also need the gradient of the component to compute the residual. I am not getting the correct result since I am using VariableGradientComponent. In this way the variable is totally constant inside the element. Is there any way to fix this?
Thanks,
Ali

use coupledGradient to retrieve a gradient within your kernel.
Do not use an auxiliary variable to store a gradient or a second derivative for anything else than postprocessing.

The source term is a vector?
Is this contributing to a vector equation (conservation of momentum?)
or a regular scalar equation.
Are your variables vector variables? What are the variables?

w and c are both scalar variables. Therefore w*grad(c) is a vector value and this is a source term for a vector equation.
Thanks,
Ali

what is this equation if you dont mind writing it down
what are you planning to use as the main variable for this equation
w and c are both computed using phase field kernel.

ok this top equation is indeed a vector equation, it s the conservation of momentum.
What is u in your simulation? Are you using Navier Stokes? and which discretization within Navier Stokes?
This is important to advise you on which type of kernel to use to contribute to this equation

I am using INSMassRZ, INSMomentumTimeDerivative and INSMomentumLaplaceFormRZ. In addition, my variables in momentum equation are velocity by its components (vel_x, vel_y) and pressure.
Thanks,
Ali
in that context, you want to use an integration by parts instead of computing the Laplacian

node.title: Execute the input file in Parallel
node.bodyText:
Dears,
My idea is to run an input file in parallel.
I'm finding that for the same input file, the solve converges with one processor but it does not if I increase the number of processors.

Hello
The default preconditioning is different in parallel.
You ll want to set your preconditioning parameters manually
Guillaume

Yes.
Some docs here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html

Thanks.
I have already read this document to find suitable preconditioning parameters because my problem is fully coupled with 5 coupled variables. With current preconditioning parameters and adaptative time-step, it's possible to go from 0.01 s to 120 s (simulation time 1600s).
So, do you think that it's possible to find easily adequate preconditioning parameters for parallel execution?
For a given physics, your best bet is to study the litterature on how to solve it numerically, then implement what is recommended using petsc_options

node.title: Patch Size Information
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am looking for more information on Patch Size used within the Mesh block. I am not able to find much information or any at all explaining what this parameter is. I have found only this information:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/mesh/FileMesh.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/index.html

Hello
That's all we have. You can dive into the code to find out more.
I've never used it
Guillaume

node.title: LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR
node.bodyText:
hello,
I'm trying to install malamute on my pc, through compiling, first I got the following error:
/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/base/MooseApp.C:411:48: error: 'class libMesh::Parallel::Communicator' has no member named 'sync_type'
to solve that I used "mamba update --all", but then when I wanted to compile again, I've got this error which I couldn't solve:
**/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/meshgenerators/MeshGenerator.C:285:18: error: 'class libMesh::Nemesis_IO' has no member named 'set_hdf5_writing'
  285 |       nemesis_io.set_hdf5_writing(false);
      |                  ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In file included from /mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build/unity_src/meshgenerators_Unity.C:66:
/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/meshgenerators/SymmetryTransformGenerator.C: In member function 'virtual std::unique_ptr<libMesh::MeshBase> SymmetryTransformGenerator::generate()':
/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/meshgenerators/SymmetryTransformGenerator.C:90:28: error: 'orient_elements' is not a member of 'libMesh::MeshTools::Modification'
   90 |   MeshTools::Modification::orient_elements(*mesh);
      |                            ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build/unity_src/outputs_png_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build/unity_src/parser_Unity.C...

make: *** [/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build.mk:148: /mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build/unity_src/meshgenerators_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
In file included from /mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build/unity_src/outputs_Unity.C:23:
/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/outputs/PetscOutput.C: In member function 'virtual void PetscOutput::solveSetup()':
/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/outputs/PetscOutput.C:151:76: error: 'LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'LIBMESH_PETSCINT_FMT'?
  151 |     PetscErrorCode ierr = SNESMonitorSet(snes, petscNonlinearOutput, this, LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR);
      |                                                                            ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      |                                                                            LIBMESH_PETSCINT_FMT
/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/src/outputs/PetscOutput.C:158:71: error: 'LIBMESH_PETSC_NULLPTR' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'LIBMESH_PETSCINT_FMT'?

      |                                                                       ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

make: *** [/mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build.mk:148: /mnt/c/moose/projects/malamute/moose/framework/build/unity_src/outputs_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1**

I would be grateful if someone help me with this issue

Hello
can you to follow this, roughly
mamba update --all
cd ~/projects/moose
git commit -am "quick save"
git clean -xfd
cd ../malamute
git commit -am "quick save"
git clean -xfd

then
make -j6

Guillaume

node.title: Material property 'strain', requested by 'TensileStrainEnergy' is not defined on block 0
node.bodyText:
I need to define a custom AuxKernel to help me calculate the tensile strain part from a total strain tensor. But when I execute the simulation it reports this error. By looking at this discussion, I know the reason is that the block name is not the same as material property name. So what is the material_property name that ComputeSmallStrain declares? The following part is the corresponding part in my input file:
[Variables]
  [disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
  [disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
    [tensile_strain_energy]
        family = LAGRANGE
        order = FIRST
    []
[]

[Kernels]
  [TensorMechanics]
    #Stress divergence kernels
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
   []
[]

[AuxKernels]
    [TensileStrainEnergy]
        type = TensileStrainEnergyAux
        rank_two_tensor = strain
        variable = tensile_strain_energy
        lambda = 120
        mu = 80
        block = 0
    []
[]
[Materials]
  [elasticity]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 0
  []
  [./strain]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    block = 0
  [../]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    block = 0
  [../]
[]
i find it in the source codes. It is called mechanical_strain.

Other options that would have worked:

output all material properties to exodus by adding output=exodus to the materials blocks
Use the show_material_properties option in the Debug block

I m glad you had a look at the code though! Good reason to open source :)
Oh, got it! Thanks a lot!
I would use elastic_strain instead of mechanical_strain. Though if your simulation is purely elastic, they are equivalent.

node.title: How to use new system with lagrangian formulation in dynamic analysis?
node.bodyText:
Hi, every one!
I met an error when I was doing dynamic analysis by setting new_system = true in DynamicTensorMechanics kernel. The error message is as follows:
*** ERROR ***
 The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".
  Material property 'stress', requested by 'TM_DynamicTensorMechanics0' is not defined on block plate
  Material property 'Jacobian_mult', requested by 'TM_DynamicTensorMechanics0' is not defined on block plate

However, the name of Cauchy stress and its jacobian should be "cauchy_stress" and "cauchy_jacobian"  for lagrangian formulation. Is it a bug and we just need to change the name from "cauchy_stress" and "cauchy_jacobian" to "stress" and "Jacobian_mult"?

Hello
the others will know more but I think you just need both the object that defines and the ones that consume this stress material property to be using the new system
Guillaume

For the new system, use the action and the InertialForce kernel to define a dynamic analysis.
Newmark-Beta and HHT-alpha time integrations are supported as usual. Rayleigh damping is not yet supported, hence eta in the InertialForce kernel has to be zero. Feel free to open an issue if you need Rayleigh damping.

Dear hugary1995,
The same error message still exists.  I guess the action you referred to should be Tensor Mechanics Master Action System, the settings are listed as follows:
[Modules/TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    newmark_beta = 0.25
    newmark_gamma = 0.5 
    density = 7750
    new_system = true
    incremental = false
    strain = finite
  []  
[]

[Kernels]
  [inertia_x]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_x
    velocity = vel_x
    acceleration = accel_x
    beta = 0.25
    gamma = 0.5
  []
  [inertia_y]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_y
    velocity = vel_y
    acceleration = accel_y
    beta = 0.25
    gamma = 0.5
  []
[]

node.title: Difference in values between processors
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I am looking at my value of temperature, calculated from a custom kernel, and is supposed to be homogeneous across the medium.
The function is only defined with respect to time.
The value of the temperature in the output file however has a region which has a lower temperature than the rest of the object.
The region that is causing the issue is being calculated by 7 of the 24 processors used (checked using ProcessorIDAux), and the processor ID is overlay with the temperature function, and the boundaries of the regions of temperature line up perfectly with that of the processors. Figure attached, see anomalous region top left.
If I define the parallel_type = DISTRIBUTED this issue seems to go away.
The issue only happens when I am using more than 8 processors, and appears to get worse with the more compute used.
Does anyone have an idea why an homogeneous value is varying depending on which processor is used?
Is this a known issue already?
I know I could just leave parallel_type = DISTRIBUTED, but id like to understand the issue for the future.
Thanks for your help,
Lloyd

Hello
Why isotropic? There's no direction to temperature. Do you mean homogeneous / constant?
What is this figure showing?
Is temperature a nonlinear variable or an auxiliary variable?
Can you share your input file?
Guillaume

I'm pretty sure this is not due to PorousFlow , as i can't see why the PorousFlow stuff would change the temperature.  Can you change T to be an AuxVariable set by a FunctionAux ?  That may allow easier debugging

I have run some more models and this is happening with as low as 5 cores. Regions calculated by certain processors have a different value to the rest. It appears the more cores the greater the magnitude of this effect.

Hello Guillaume and Andy,
I mean that the temperature is constant across all space at the same time.
The images attached show the temperature value varying between processors when it should be constant at the same time step.
I have completely stripped back my code to narrow down the issue and it appears the issue lies in the calculation from my custom kernel.
Here is my stripped back input file to find the source of the issue:
[Mesh]
    [plate]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 2
        xmax = 0.8
        nx = 120
        ymax = 0.8
        ny = 120
    []
  
[]

[Variables]
    [T]
        initial_condition = 293
    []
[]

[Kernels]
    [T_func]
        type = ADFunctionVariable
        variable = T
        function = temp_func
    []
[]
[Functions]
    [temp_func]
      type = ParsedFunction  # YOUR TEMP FUNC HERE
      value = '298 + 202*(1 - exp(-t/80))'
    []
[]
[Preconditioning]
    [smp]
        type = SMP
        full = true
        petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
        petsc_options_value = ' lu       mumps'
    []
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
    # dt = 0.2
    end_time = 400
    [TimeStepper]
        type = SolutionTimeAdaptiveDT
        dt = 0.5
    []

    automatic_scaling = true
    nl_abs_tol = 2e-9
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
    print_linear_residuals = false
    []
[]

Hence, the issue must be within the ADFunctionVariable kernel.
Find the src code for ADFunctionVariable here:
HEADER
#pragma once

#include "ADKernelValue.h"

// class ADFunctionVariable;
class Function;


class ADFunctionVariable : public ADKernelValue
{
public:
  static InputParameters validParams();
  ADFunctionVariable(const InputParameters & parameters);

protected:
  virtual ADReal precomputeQpResidual() override;
  const Function & _f;
};

C CODE
// Kernel to set a variable equal to a function of space and time
// (Variable should be h if used to drive mould height)

#include "ADFunctionVariable.h"
#include "Function.h"

registerMooseObject("MyApp", ADFunctionVariable);

InputParameters
ADFunctionVariable::validParams()
{
  InputParameters params = ADKernelValue::validParams();
  params.addClassDescription("Sets the variable equal to a specified function (of space and time)");
  params.addParam<FunctionName>("function", "The function");
  return params;
}

ADFunctionVariable::ADFunctionVariable(const InputParameters & parameters)
  : ADKernelValue(parameters), _f(getFunction("function"))
{
}

ADReal
ADFunctionVariable::precomputeQpResidual()
{
  return _u[_qp] - _f.value(_t, _q_point[_qp]);
}

Temperature value:

^^^ This should all be one value and hence the same colour
Processor ID:

Thanks for the help!

By the way, i wonder whether your Function should be an ADParsedFunction?  In your case it doesn't matter, but perhaps it's clearer for future readers that in principle it could depend on some Variables.

Yes I think it is the ADParsedFunction, good spot. I have changed it locally and I am still getting the same incorrect results unfortunately.
Thanks Andy

what's your convergence history?
can you force more non linear iterations using nl_forced_its
by the way, if T is meant to just be equal to this Function, then the way to do this is to use a FunctionAux and have T be an auxiliary variable.
If not, and it's just like this because you made a MWE, then it's ok that way.

Yes this is currently a MWE of the situation as T will be changed later.
nl_forced_its causes issues due to floating point error:

Time Step 1, time = 0.25, dt = 0.25
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 2.990296e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 2.970512e-16
 2 Nonlinear |R| = 5.749818e-17
 3 Nonlinear |R| = 5.718915e-17
 4 Nonlinear |R| = 5.707936e-17
 5 Nonlinear |R| = 5.705842e-17
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LOCAL_MIN iterations 5
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
Solve failed... cutting timestep

I have also tried having nl_abs_tol = 1e-16 (just larger than value from floating point) and it outputs:
Time Step 24, time = 44.2487, dt = 4.47715
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.551778e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 3.319341e-16
 Solve Converged!

However the output still exhibits the strange behaviour, with large variation in temperature (~1e17 times bigger than the abs tol)
Additional points:

Not all numbers of cores have issues, e.g 11 cores causes issues, but 12 cores and its fine.
The strange behaviour occurs after a certain time step, consistent to that number of cores when run again with the same tolerance, but varies when using a different number of cores or a different tolerance.

Plot on the left is T plotted along the diagonal, on the right is T over the whole plate
Time step 89:

Time step 90:

this looks like a solver issue.
Can you turn off the line search with line_search = 'none'
and keep two forced non linear iterations

That seems to have fixed it.
What wind you recommend going forward?
having parallel_type = distributed also seemed to solve the issue, is that related?
Going forward you need to look at the residuals and make sure a false convergence is not being accepted.

These are the residuals for an example. The strange behaviour begins at time step 32. The residuals before and after this behaviour appear almost identical.

Time Step 30, time = 82.247, dt = 7.93155
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.999619e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 9.480531e-17
 Solve Converged!

Time Step 31, time = 90.9717, dt = 8.7247
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.964952e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 5.717617e-16
 Solve Converged!

Time Step 32, time = 100.569, dt = 9.59717
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.521614e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 1.230550e-16
 Solve Converged!

Time Step 33, time = 111.126, dt = 10.5569
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.174585e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 3.550751e-16
 Solve Converged!

Time Step 34, time = 122.738, dt = 11.6126
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.097601e-02
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 3.207153e-16
 Solve Converged!

I do not understand how I am meant to spot the false convergence with these.
What change does line_search = 'none' make to the solve and why would that fix the issue?

I have just printed the value of the function in the .C file to the consol.
The value of the function output is correct and consistent across all qps even when the outputs to exodus, as seen in the post processor are not.
i.e value of function (which is correct) =/= value at post processor for all qp
did you print from all ranks? you need to pass --keep-cout on the command line to do so
when I add --keep-cout I can see that the value of the function is going wrong, and is sometimes different within a block where it should be constant

ok all you need to do is avoid the ParsedFunction if you need to keep going.
Are you using multiple nodes on these runs? Or just multiple CPUs on the same node?

Currently multiple cpus same node for this mwe, however I will be using multiple nodes in the future.
I need to couple time dependence to a function... can this be done without ParsedFunction?

you can write your own function for that.
There's also a number of 1 or multi-D functions which will do time dependence if you set the (or one of the) axis to time.

OK, thanks.
Is this a local issue or is it a Moose issue?
Tagging our FParser expert @dschwen as the issue seems to be coming from ParsedMaterial. Perhaps removing .jitcache isn't enough? Check if there are files named tmp_* in the working directory.

@hugary1995  there is tmp_jit_* inside the .gitignore
should this be deleted?

no the .gitignore is fine.
this makes sure we dont git add jit files by accident
OK, thought so

Ive run 3 different versions of Moose I have available on the cluster using 14 cores.
Dates of versions: 22/03/31, 22/05/17, 22/09/28 left to right
It looks fine in the march version, however by the may version the issue has occurred. (same input file in each case)

I tried again on a linux platform with 1-180 processes with the FunctionAux and a ParsedFunction and could not reproduce this.
Can you please run the diagnostic script in moose/scripts and we ll see if we can get a platform close to yours to reproduce this
I'm looking forward to you two getting to the bottom of this!

Hi Guillaume,
I hope you had a good weekend.
The diagnostic file is attached. Some paths have been redacted with [] fro security purposes.
Thank you for your help.

The possibly final word on this is that there was an issue with JIT in parallel on some platforms
It ended up being fixed there
#24208
If you still have you could try again to see if that fixed it

node.title: Stress free temperature
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
In  "ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain" Can we provide a function in stress free temperature? In most examples I saw, it takes an constant value?
Thanks,
Deepak

Hello
You ll want to check the other strain models for functions.
You want a functions right? like a pre-determined function of space and time, not a variable
Guillaume

Yes, I would like to input a function varying in space as stress_free_temperature instead of a constant value.
Deepak

The stress free temperature takes a variable.

I would like to input a function varying in space as stress_free_temperature instead of a constant value.

You can define a spatially varying auxvariable using your function.

Use a FunctionAux for that
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/FunctionAux.html
